data.title: 2013 Calendar of Events for The Irish American Crossroads Festival
data.meta_description: 2011 Calendar of Events for The Crossroads Irish-American Festival
data.text:
10th ANNUAL â¨

CROSSROADS IRISH-AMERICAN FESTIVAL

CALENDAR OF EVENTS

â¨

March 9th - April 26th

2013

Children's Hour of Music, Song & Dance

Crossroads welcomes the talented Autumn Rhodes and Darcy Noonan and the high-stepping Brosnan School of Irish Dance to the Childrenâs Hour, a perennial Festival favorite.Â Since 2010, Autumn Rhodes and Darcy Noonan (of The Jammy Dodgers) have been bringing traditional Irish music with a novel twist to the Bay Area and beyond. From the high-energy driving rhythm of Irish jigs and reels to slower-paced airs and sean-nÃ³s ('old style') songs (sung in both Irish and English), they stay well in touch with the roots of the music, while infusing it with their own special style. The duo will play and explain several instruments, including fiddle, Irish flute, concertina, and tin whistle. Children will also have the chance to learn and sing along to a few Irish Gaelic children's songs.

The Brosnan School of Irish Dance will perform jigs, reels, and other high-kicking steps!

Time:Â 11:00 am - 12:00 noonÂ

Location: San Francisco Public Library, Fisher Children's Center, 100 Larkin Street @ Grove, SF

Nights in Shanaglish â US Film Premiere About Live Session Recordings in Shanaglish, Ireland

Crossroads' 10th Anniversary launches with the U.S. Premiere of a documentary film, Nights in Shanaglish, a unique project focused on the culture of traditional Irish music sessions and the making of an album in Shanaglish, County Galway, Ireland.Â Vincey Keehan, a native of Shanaglish who has lived in San Francisco for more than 30 years, brought this project to life along with Paddy Egan of County Wicklow.Â The film, directed by Firgus Tighe, focuses on the process of recording live performances and captures the connection between performers, pub owner, and local characters.Â Live music before the film is shown.Â Q & A to follow.

Time: Musical Performance: 1:00 pm.Â Film: 1:45 p.m.Â

Location: SF Public Library, Koret Auditorium, 100 Larkin Street @ Grove, SF

A special thanks to the Friends of the San Francisco Public Library for their partial support of events on this day.

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 13th

The Diaries of Denis & Bridget Oliver:Â A Dramatic Reading & Exhibit Crossroads and the California Historical Society present this first-ever exhibit and dramatic reading based on the writings of two emigrants to San Francisco who survived An Gorta MÃ³r (The Great Hunger/Famine) and lived in San Francisco from 1849 -1880s.

Dramatic readers RenÃ©e Gibbons and Tom McCarthy will read selections from the diaries.Â Harp music provided by Mitch Landy. Readings directed by Elizabeth Creely.Â

Time: 6:00 p.m.

Located at the California Historical Society, 678 Mission Street@3rd Street, San Francisco

THURSDAY, MARCH 14th

Nights in Shanaglish: Live Performance & CD/DVD/Vinyl Release Party

A special night celebrating the US release of a unique multi-media recording.Â Nights in Shanaglish is a production featuring song, music, story and dance documented during a series of live session recordings in Whelan's Pub in Shanaglish, Co. Galway, Ireland.Â The project includes a CD and old-time vinyl album of the live recordings as well as a documentary film about the making of these recordings.Â Â

Don't miss the chance to see the documentary film, Nights in Shanaglish (directed by Firgus Tighe) on March 9th at 1p.m. at the San Francisco Public Library, 100 Larkin Street, San Francisco. See details above.

Live performance will feature producers Vincey Keehan and Paddy Egan as well as musicians and performers Niall Finnigan, Rosie Keehan, Anthony McGrath, Paul O'Driscoll, Brian OâHalloran, and Mary Noonan, all visiting from Co. Galway, Ireland.Â Â Â Â

Time: 8:00 p.m.Â

Location: The Plough and the Stars Irish Pub, 116 Clement Street @ 2nd Avenue, San Francisco

This event is FREE.Â Â

WEDNESDAY, MARCH 20th

Live Performance featuring Laurence Nugent, Paddy Egan & Friends

Another remarkable night of music at the Crossroads features virtuoso flute and whistle player, Laurence Nugent, performing along with Wicklow concertina player, Paddy Egan.Â

Time:Â 9:00 p.m.

Location: The Plough and the Stars Irish Pub, 116 Clement Street @ 2nd Avenue, San Francisco

This event is FREE.Â

One of Irish music's recognized master musicians.

-Irish Music Magazine.

Laurence Nugent is a virtuoso All-Ireland winning champion of the flute and tin whistle from county Fermanagh in Northern Ireland. He took first prize in a number of competitions in the late 80's before going on to win the senior All-Ireland Championships in 1994 and 1995 at the Fleadh Cheoil na hÃireann, the All-Ireland Music Festival, one of the largest festivals in Europe.

A well established performer on the Celtic music scene, Laurence has toured throughout the U.S, Europe, and Japan over the last two decades performing with scores of musicians including: The Chieftains, Shane McGowan, Van Morrison, Derek Warfield and the Young Wolftones, Liam O Maonlai of the Hothouse Flowers, Kevin Burke, Liz Carroll, Martin Hayes, Dennis Cahill, Paddy Keenan, and Arty McGlynn.

Paddy Egan was born in Parkbridge, near Shillelagh in the foothills of the Wicklow mountains. He has played the concertina since he was seven years old. He has often times travelled out to the Bay area to meet and with many of the local musicians over the years. At the moment, he is studying for his PhD at King's College, London, where he is exploring the connection between music and memory in repatriated collections of sound.

SATURDAY, MARCH 23rd

Irish-American Stories Workshop: Creating Narratives from Family Records

Crossroads is pleased to partner with the Patrick J. Dowling Library at the United Irish Cultural Center to explore Irish American stories with this facilitated workshop by Margaret Cooley, author and educator.

Sometimes all we have left of our ancestors is a photograph, a marriage record or a Mass card. Margaret Cooley will give a talk and teach a workshop on how she began without any records, stories or photographs and found enough information to recreate a family story and write a book, The McQueeneys: From Ireland to America.

Participants may bring a family photograph or record and will have an opportunity to access ancestry records at the workshop. Margaret will assist participants in using vital records and photographs to begin to tell their family stories and make their own books.

Cost: $20 for workshop materials including the book (no one turned away for lack of funds)

Time: 11:00 a.m.-1:00 p.m.

Location: The United Irish Cultural Center, Patrick J. Dowling Library, 2700 45th Avenue, San Francisco

MUNI: Underground: L Taraval, Bus Lines 23 and 18

SUNDAY, MARCH 24th

Oral Histories of the Irish in San Francisco: An Afternoon of Storytelling

Crossroads offers our third annual event honoring the life histories of participants in the Crossroads Irish Oral History Archive of the San Francisco Bay Area.Â This afternoon gathering will highlight the individual stories of several Oral History Archive participants and create a space for audience members of this generation of immigrants to share their own stories.Â Bring the whole family!Â

The Crossroads Irish-American Festival is creating the first-ever oral history archive of the Irish and Irish-American communities of the Bay Area. This oral history project is composed of audio and video recordings of individuals telling their own stories about their own experiences of emigrating to or growing up in the Bay Area.

If you or someone you know would like to be part of this archive, please contact us.

Time: 2:00-4:00 p.m.

Location: The United Irish Cultural Center, St. Francis Room, 2700 45th Avenue @ Sloat, San Francisco

A special thanks to the Irish Governmentâs Emigrant Support Programme for its generous support of the Crossroads Oral History Archive.

SUNDAY, APRIL 7th

Irish-American Writers of the San Francisco Bay Area: Readings and Explorations

Crossroads is pleased to partner with the USF College of Arts and Sciences in an afternoon highlighting premiere Irish-American writers of the San Francisco Bay Area and exploring the rich history of Irish-American writing in this region.Â Join us in celebrating current writers and excavating this literary landscape where Irish-Americans have been writing for over 150 years.Â Featured writers include:Â Catherine Brady, Terence Clarke, Linda Norton and Eddie Stack.

Facilitation:Â Margaret McPeake

Time: 2:00-4:00 p.m.Â

Location: USF Main Campus, McLaren Conference Center, Room 250, San Francisco

This event is co-sponsored by the USF College of Arts and Sciences.

Catherine Brady is the author of three short story collections, including Curled in the Bed of Love, winner of the 2002 Flannery OâConnor Award for Short Fiction, and The Mechanics of Falling, winner of the 2010 Northern California Book Award for Fiction. Her stories have appeared in numerous literary journals and anthologies, including Best American Short Stories 2004. She is also the author of a craft book, Story Logic and the Craft of Fiction, and a biography of a Nobel laureate, Elizabeth Blackburn and the Story of Telomeres: Deciphering the Ends of DNA. She is the Academic Director of the MFA in Writing Program at the University of San Francisco.

Terence Clarke has published three novels: My Father in the Night, The King of Rumah Nadai and A Kiss for SeÃ±or Guevara, and two story collections: The Day Nothing Happened and Little Bridget and The Flames of Hell.

Of My Father In The Night, Publisher's Weekly said, "A probing, amazingly vivid portrait of an Irish-American family seething with emotional, political and inter-generational conflict.â Malcolm Margolin, publisher of Heyday Books, writes about Little Bridget and The Flames of Hell, âWhen I first got into publishing thirty-five years ago, it was with the hope of publishing literature of this integrity, rendered with such skill and bigness of heart. "

Terry is Director of Publishing at Red Room Press. (www.redroom.com) His new novel The Notorious Dream of JesÃºs LÃ¡zaro will be published later this year. He lives in San Francisco.

Linda Norton is the author of The Public Gardens:Â Poems and History (Pressed Wafer, 2011; introduction by Fanny Howe), a finalist for a Los Angeles Times Book Prize in 2012. She works at The Bancroft Library at the University of California, Berkeley. She grew up in Boston, lived in Brooklyn for many years, and now lives in Oakland. Go to thepublicgardens.blogspot.com for more information.

Eddie Stack is from County Clare, Ireland. He is the author of three collections of short stories, three novellas and a novel. He has received several accolades for his fiction, including an American Small Press of the Year Award, and a Top 100 Irish-American Award. His work has appeared in literary reviews and anthologies worldwide, including Fiction, Confrontation, Whispers & Shouts, Southwords and Criterion; State of the Art: Stories from New Irish Writers; Irish Christmas Stories, Cuadrivio, The Clare Anthology and Fiction in the Classroom. He was co-founder of the Irish Arts Foundation and artistic director of the San Francisco Celtic Music & Arts Festival. His work has been translated into Spanish, German and Dutch. Eddie Stack teaches at U.C. Berkeley, California. More info at www.eddiestack.com

THURSDAY, APRIL 18th

Two Irish Poets: A Reading, with Patrick Cotter and Matthew Sweeney

A remarkable opportunity to hear two highly acclaimed Irish poets, Patrick Cotter and Matthew Sweeney, read from their work.Â

Time: 7:00-9:00 p.m.

Location: BookShop West Portal, 80 West Portal Avenue, San Francisco

The best of Cotter's writing is solid poetry, intensely imagist, and speaks deeply and sincerely to real and universal human concerns.

- World Literature Today

Patrick Cotter was born in Cork in 1963 where he still lives. His published work includes several chapbooks, the verse novella The Misogynistâs Blue Nightmare (Raven Arts Press, 1990) and the poetry collections, Perplexed Skin (Arlen House 2008) and Making Music (Three Spires Press 2009). His work has appeared in many anthologies including Separate Islands: Contemporary British and Irish poetry (Quarry, Ontario) Irish Poetry Now (Wolfhound) Jumping off Shadows - Some Contemporary Irish Poets (Cork University Press) The Irish Eros (Gill & Macmillan) The Backyards of Heaven (Newfoundland) Something Beginning with P (O'Brien Press) and in The Great Book of Ireland.Â His translations of the Estonian poet Andres Ehin are collected in the book Moosebeetle Swallow (Southword Editions). His play Beauty and the Stalker was produced at the Granary Theatre, Cork in 2000 and he has published short fiction in journals and newspapers.

A poet of obsession and ritual...often elusive or mysterious...enlivened with his saturnine, uncomfortably insistent humour...Ambitious and troubling, linking Ireland to the Black Sea and madness to history, grim as death and very funny.

â Sean O'Brien, Guardian

Matthew Sweeney was born in Lifford, Co. Donegal in 1952.Â He has lived principally in London from the mid seventies until the late nineties. Since then he has lived primarily in Berlin and Timosoara, Romania. More, he has settled in Cork in Ireland. Sweeney has published not only many poetry collections for adults but also several poetry collections for children and two childrenâs novels. Writing Poetry, which he co-wrote with John Hartley Williams, appeared in 1997, and he has co-edited two anthologies of poems. He has held several fellowships and writer-in-residence positions, most recently at University College Cork. He won the Prudence Farmer Prize in 1984, the Cholmondely Award in 1999, a Henfield Writing Fellowship in 1986, and several bursaries from the Arts Councils of Ireland and England. He was nominated for the T.S. Eliot award for Black Moon (2007). Horse Music Bloodaxe 2013 is his most recent collection.

A special thanks to Culture Ireland for its partial support of this event.

FRIDAY, APRIL 26th

Irish Traditional Music Legends:Â Kevin Burke and John Carty

Come join us to hear two of Ireland's finest musicians. Virtuoso fiddle player, Kevin Burke, has been on the forefront of traditional music for over 30 years, while John Carty, recipient of the Traditional Musician of the Year Award, is one of the most accomplished Irish multi-instrumentalists alive today.Â

Doors:Â 7:00 p.m.Â Show:Â 8:00 p.m.Â

Location: Brick and Mortar Music Hall, 1710 Mission Street @ Duboce, San FranciscoÂ

Cost: $15-$20. Â Info & tix: www.brickandmortarmusic.com

This event is a co-production with FreshEire.

Lyric, fluid and precisely as tricky as he needs to beâ¦probably the greatest Irish fiddler living. ---- The Village Voice

Kevin Burke's fiddle playing has been at the forefront of traditional music for over 30 years.Â Whether solo or accompanied, on record or in concert, Burke is an immensely engaging performer. He has been established as a first class musician ever since his work in the early 1970âs (with such renowned performers as Arlo Guthrie, Christy Moore and the Bothy Band and with his far-reaching solo album, If the Cap Fits).Â During his long musical career Kevin has earned international acclaim in both Europe and America as a solo performer, a teacher and as a member of some of folk musicâs foremost groups including Celtic Fiddle Festival, and Patrick Street. He is also a featured member of Grammy winner Tim OâBrienâs wonderful crossover band, The Crossing. Kevin is a National Endowment for the Arts 2002 National Heritage Fellowship recipient, the USA's highest honor for excellence in the folk and traditional arts. Previous National Heritage Fellows include B.B. King, Doc Watson, and Bill Monroe. 2010 saw Kevinâs induction to the Oregon Music Hall of Fame. He was very honored to receive such a tribute from his adopted home state.Â Â www.kevinburke.comÂ Â

One of the most accomplished Irish multi-instrumentalists alive. The flourishing diaspora of Irish traditional music had no finer exponent than John Carty â¦Â

---Earle Hitchner, Irish Echo

John Carty is one of Ireland's finest traditional musicians having been awarded the Irish Television station, TG4's Traditional Musician of the Year in 2003.Â Carty has three solo fiddle albums, two banjo albums, two group albums and a sprinkling of recorded tenor guitar and flute music recordings under his belt. Born in London, John has established himself among the elite in Irish traditional music and as a staunch supporter of its preservation. Carty developed his love for fiddle, banjo, and flute, all of which he has mastered, through his multi-instrumentalist father who was a member of the Glenside Ceili Band in London in the 1960's.Â With a firm foundation of both talent and knowledge of the tradition, John has been a welcome addition to many of the great bands of today, including Patrick Street, The Chieftains, and DeDanaan, as well as his remarkable solo career.

All festival events are free to the public unless otherwise indicated.

For more information, please call (415) 810-3774

or email info@irishamericancrossroads.org
